dataset.title: Long-term precipitation chemistry patterns and dry deposition chemistry: Andrews Experimental Forest rain collector samples

address.deliveryPoint: US Forest Service ;Pacific NW Research Station ;3200 SW Jefferson Way

Department of Biology;University of New Mexico;

section.para: Long-term records of precipitation chemistry reflect the sampling effort and laboratory analysis initiated in 1969. The study examines nutrient inputs via precipitation in small watersheds and examines nutrient budgets. The original objective was to evaluate the significance of nutrient inputs and outputs from a forest soil-plant system after timber harvest compared to control watersheds. The study has evolved into a general monitoring effort for precipitation chemistry that is among the least contaminated of any within the USA. This study is conducted in conjunction with Andrews streamflow chemistry (CF002) and the U.S. National Atmospheric Deposition Program (NADP) (CP001).

additionalInfo.para:
Fredriksen, R. L. Study Plan--Nutrient cycle of a small watershed in the Douglas-fir region of the western slope of the Cascade range in Oregon. 1967. PNW-FSL-1602-22
Fredriksen, R. L. 1972. Nutrient budget of a Douglas-fir forest on an experimental watershed in western Oregon. In Proc. Research on Coniferous Forest Ecosystems -A Symposium, Bellingham, Washington. March 23-24, 1972. (Publ. by USDA, For. Serv. Pac. Northwest For. and Range Exp. Stn.).
Grier, C. C., D. W. Cole, C. T. Dyrness, and R. L. Fredriksen. 1974. Nutrient cycling in 37-and 450-year-old Douglas-fir ecosystems. In Integrated research in the coniferous forest biome, Bull. No. 5. R. H. Waring and R. L. Edmonds, eds. Conif. For. Biome, Ecosys. Anal. Stud. US/IBP. p. 1-34.

intellectualRights.para: Welcome to the H. J. Andrews LTER Database. Our intentions are to make our data as freely available as possible (See Data Availability). Our data sets consist of long-term research study data with accompanying documentation (metadata). Spatial and non-spatial data sets are available as well as software and models. We encourage the use of our data sets, but as a professional courtesy we ask that data users read and agree to the terms of our Data Use Agreement. It is considered a matter of professional ethics to acknowledge the work of other scientists that results in data used in subsequent research. Therefore, Andrews Forest researchers request appropriate citation and acknowledgement for subsequent distribution or publication of any work derived from these data sets. Data users are strongly encouraged to consider consultation, collaboration and/or co-authorship with original investigators.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Andrews Experimental Forest within the Willamette National Forest. Sample sites are the H. J. Andrews Administrative site (PRIMET) and Watershed 7. The precipitation collector at the administrative site (RCADMN) represents nutrient input for Andrews Watersheds 2, 9, and 10. The original Hi-15 precipitation collector (RCHI15) and the current NADP-like collector (RCHIR7, RCHID7) represent nutrient input for the Andrews Hi-15 Watersheds 6, 7 and 8.

address.deliveryPoint: US Forest Service ;Pacific NW Research Station ;3200 SW Jefferson Way

section.title: Experimental Design - CP002
section.para:
The rain collector at the administrative site (low elevation)site) is analyzed for nutrient inputs. This rain collector is paired with streamflow nutrient outflows on WS 9 (control), WS 10 (clearcut), and WS2 (control).

The rain collector at the mid elevation site is also analyzed for nutrient inputs. This rain collector and dry deposition collector (positioned mid-slope WS 7) are paired with streamflow nutrient outflows on WS 8 (control), WS 6 (clearcut), and WS7 (shelterwood cut). The original HI15 rain collector was established mid-slope WS 6 until removal in 1989.

Dates in data file refer to end date of collection period. Data is summarized by water year: October 1 to September 30. The following sample codes may be of interest: 1) "P" for partial or incomplete sample, 2) "Y" represents an end-of-year value that is based on the overall concentration of the sampling period, but is not an actual sample.

section.title: Field Methods - CP002
section.para:
Precipitation chemistry is sampled at a low elevation site (430m) and a mid-elevation site (999m). Samples are stored in polyethylene containers and analyzed at 3 week intervals. Prior to 1988, samples from both sites were collected and transported to the Corvallis lab for analysis on a 3 week basis. Since October, 1988, both sample sites have been collected weekly. Weekly samples are stored in a cooler at the Andrews and transported to the Corvallis lab for analysis on a 3-week basis, and weekly samples are analyzed individually.

Originally, collectors at both sites were open orifice (Polyethylene carboy jug with funnel). At the H. J. Andrews administrative low elevation site (RCADMN), precipitation was collected at the top of a 55 ft tower located in a clearcut. Water was stored in a polyethylene container inside an insulated shelter at the tower base. On January 20, 1982, the collector was moved to a 5 ft platform within 10 meters of the original location, and the polyethylene container is stored in an uninsulated bucket on the platform. At the mid-elevation site (RCHI15) precipitation was collected at the top of a 10 ft pole located in a clearcut near the top of Watershed #6. Water was stored in a polyethylene container inside an insulated shelter at the base of the pole. In October, 1988, a new collection site (RCHIR7) was started in a shelterwood with subsequent overstory removal near the top of Watershed # 7. An NADP-type wet/dry deposition sampler mounted on top of a 5 ft tower was used instead of the open orifice samplers used at the original site. The water is stored in polyethylene containers inside an uninsulated housing on top of the sampler. The "dry" side (RCHID7) container is collected and analyzed 2-4 times per year. The new (RCHIR7) and old (RCHI15) mid-elevation sites were collected and analyzed concurrently for 9 weeks before the old site was discontinued.

methodStep.instrumentation:
Andrews-designed collector (RCADMN, RCHI15): An open orifice (polyethylene jug with funnel) located on a tower.
NADP-type wet/dry deposition sampler (RCHIR7/RCHID7): The orifice of this collector is only open during precipitation events. It is controlled by a heated grid sensor which moves a cover from the "wet" side to the "dry"side when precipitation covers the grid of the sensor. The cover moves back to the "wet" side as the water is evaporated off the sensor grid by the heating element.

section.title: Laboratory Methods - CP002
section.para:
Laboratory procedures: ( Descriptions of lab methods are listed in CCAL's Master Procedures Manual)
Note: Diss. Total N values from 6/1/1970-6/21/1971 do not include free ammonia (NH4-N)

Official compilation of water analyses begins with the WY 1969 (10/1/68). The first year, water was stored at 0 degrees C until operation of the PNW-1653 lab in spring, 1969. Originally, samples are analyzed for suspended sediment, alkalinity, pH, ammonia nitrogen, nitrate, nitrite, dissolved organic nitrogen, ortho and total phosphorus, sodium, potassium, calcium, magnesium, and silica. Sulfate was determined for WY 1972 and sulfate and chloride in WY 1979. Aluminum, iron, manganese, and nitrite were below levels of detection and were subsequently dropped from analysis. Analysis of specific conductivity was added in Dec 1974 and total P on an unfiltered sample in Oct 1974. Analysis of total N on an unfiltered sample was started in June 1978. In general, duplicates were run on all analyses until Oct 1983, and are currently conducted randomly. Sulphur and Chloride were analyzed at the University of Washington until 2004, and are now conducted at Oregon State. Dissolved organic carbon was initiated in 2003.

Currently, all samples are filtered upon arrival at the Corvallis lab and pH, alkalinity, conductivity, and autoanalyzer runs (NO3-N, NH4-N, SI) are made immediately. All analyses are completed within 6 weeks. Generally, samples are stored at 0 degrees C if not analyzed immediately.

section.title: Processing Procedure - CP002
section.para: A Visual Foxpro program (pio_fox) combines nutrient concentration data with precipitation to produce outputs in kilogram per hectare by water year, and creates annual nutrient concentrations. This program replaces the original PIO99 Fortran program in March 2005.

codeDefinition.definition: No precipitation recorded for period. For saved sample (type='S'), precipitation for this period is added into the following period.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Suspended sediment concentration; method: nonfiltrable residue, gravimetric

codeDefinition.definition: Value is below detection limit for analysis

attribute.attributeDefinition: Silica as silicon concentration; method: automated molybdenum blue

codeDefinition.definition: Value is below detection limit for analysis
Value is below detection limit for analysis

attribute.attributeDefinition: Alkalinity as bicarbonate carbon (HCO3-C) method: electrometric titration to pH 4.5

codeDefinition.definition: Value is below detection limit for analysis
Value is below detection limit for analysis

attribute.attributeDefinition: Sample volume from precipitation collector; for dry deposition sample - includes any precipitation collected and DI water added to sample for analysis

codeDefinition.definition: Sample volume value is questionable - typically implies volume is measured correctly, but volume does not represent the entire collection period
Volume is precipitation plus added DIW (usually 250 ml). concentration values are based on this volume.
Volume of lab water (DIW) added to dry bucket (usually 250 ml). concentration values are based on this volume.
Volume is precipitation in dry bucket (liters). Concentration values are based on this volume. No DIW added to the precipitation water.
